children.value: and investigate the observed convergence more closely. Recall that above we calculated

children.html: g′(p)≈−0.42g'(p)\approx-0.42g′(p)≈−0.42

children.value: Here is the fixed-point iteration. This time we keep track of the whole sequence of approximations.

g(x) = x - p(x)
x = [2.1]
for k = 1:12
    push!(x, g(x[k]))
end
x
It’s illuminating to construct and plot the sequence of errors.

err = @. abs(x - rmax)
plot(0:12, err;
    m=:o,
    xaxis=("iteration number"),  yaxis=("error", :log10),
    title="Convergence of fixed-point iteration")
It’s quite clear that the convergence quickly settles into a linear rate. We could estimate this rate by doing a least-squares fit to a straight line. Keep in mind that the values for small

children.html: kkk

children.value: should be left out of the computation, as they don’t represent the linear trend.
We can exponentiate the slope to get the convergence constant
The error should therefore decrease by a factor of
at each iteration. We can check this easily from the observed data.
